<ul>
 <li><strong>. . . </strong> and Anatomy Armadillos are prolific diggers Many species use their sharp claws to dig for food such as grubs and to dig dens The Nine-banded Armadillo prefers to build burrows in moist soil near the creeks streams and arroyos around which it<strong>  . . .</strong></li>
 <li><strong>. . . </strong> by fleeing often into thorny patches from which their armor protects them or digging to safety Only the South American three-banded armadillos Tolypeutes rely heavily on their armor for protection When threatened by a predator Tolypeutes<strong>. . . </strong></li>
 <li><strong>. . . </strong> narrow bodies of water which often doubles its size Armadillos use their claws for digging and finding food as well as for making their homes in burrows They dig their burrows with their claws only making a single corridor where they fit<strong>. . . </strong></li>
 <li><strong>. . . </strong> They have five clawed toes on the hindfeet and three to five toes with heavy digging claws on the forefeet Armadillos have a large number of cheek teeth which are not divided into premolars and molars but usually have incisors or canines<strong>. . . </strong></li>
 </ul>

text_result.title: Aardvark - Wikipedia for Schools
text_result.fulltxt:
<ul>
 <li><strong>. . . </strong> name Orycteropus afer Pallas 1766 Aardvark range map The Aardvark Orycteropus afer Digging foot is a medium-sized burrowing nocturnal mammal native to Africa It is sometimes called antbear anteater Cape anteater after the Cape of Good Hope <strong>  . . .</strong></li>
 <li><strong>. . . </strong> exceptionally fast digger but otherwise moves fairly slowly Its claws enable it to dig through the extremely hard crust of a termite or ant mound quickly avoiding the dust by sealing the nostrils When successful the aardvar s long as long as 30<strong>. . . </strong></li>
 <li><strong>. . . </strong> Its keen hearing warns it of predators lions leopards hyenas and pythons Aside from digging out ants and termites the aardvark also excavates burrows in which to live temporary sites are scattered around the home range as refuges and a main burrow<strong>. . . </strong></li>
 <li><strong>. . . </strong> termites at 14 weeks and is weaned by 16 weeks At six months of age it is able to dig its own burrows but it will often remain with the mother until the next mating season and is sexually capable by the season after that Aardvarks can live to be<strong>. . . </strong></li>
 <li><strong>. . . </strong> aardvar s main predators are lions leopards hunting dogs and pythons Aardvarks can dig fast or run in zigzag fashion to elude enemies but if all else fails they will strike with their claws tail and shoulders sometimes flipping onto their backs to<strong>. . . </strong></li>
 </ul>
